Joseph is 33 years old and is married. He has three children ranging from 3 to 13 years old. He has been an active farmer for seven years and currently employs one farmhand on his farm in Kitale, Western Kenya. He runs a salon in the local market to supplement his farming income.

Joseph has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy more poultry birds for his business. He says the expansion of the business will improve his income and enable him to meet his family's basic needs. He is confident he will be able to repay the loan based on his experience in the poultry business.

Joseph says his challenges are the high costs incurred in managing poultry diseases.

loans.use: to purchase poultry birds.

loans.name: Orlando

texts.en:
Orlando has been a farmer for nearly 15 years. He patiently manages his corn field to provide for his living expenses. Orlando is 39 years old and is married. He and his wife have been blessed with six children. He dreams of improving his farming business so that he can send all his children to a higher level of education and improve their standard of living. 

Orlando only generates an income of P25,000 from cropping due to his obligation to the traders where he gets his farm inputs. According to him, his profit is not enough for his family because of the expenses for tuition fees and household expenses. 

He would like to ask for financial assistance in the amount of P27,000, which would allow him to pay for the labor costs of transplanting and plowing the corn field as well as to buy farm inputs to maintain his farming business. Through his requested loan, he will no longer be subject to high interest rates. Also, he could minimize his expenses because he will not be paying high interest rates. In this way, he could save some money and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for the labor costs of transplanting and plowing the corn field as well as to buy farm inputs to maintain his farming business.

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en: Roberto is a married man with two children. Roberto is 33 years old and he lives in the Philippines. Roberto owns and operates a business venture, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community to earn a living. He has been in this business for four years. Each month, he earns 6,000 doing this type of business. He requested a loan of 7,000 to purchase fishing materials. Roberto has been a member of GDMPC for a year. In the future, Roberto wants to build a house and for his children to finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials.

loans.name: Philip

texts.en: Philip is 30 years old. He is married and has one child who is 8 years old.  He sells tablecloths and fabric to earn a living.  He has been in this business for five years. He has managed to provide for his family including educating his child with the income from his business. Philip also has a motorbike transport (bodaboda) business to supplement his family's income. Philip has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to buy tablecloths.

loans.use: to buy tablecloths.

loans.name: Amd 28 Mandiri Group

texts.en:
Fatmawati is 49 years old and married with three children.  She is pictured above standing in the middle of the group.  One of her children is studying at university while the other two are in high school and junior high school.  She has been selling clothing and electronic equipment on credit for 26 years around her neighborhood.  The business allows her to help her husband by supplementing his income as a caterer and also helps pay school fees for the children.  She hopes that all of her children can succeed in school and attend through university.  She is now requesting her first loan with VisionFund Indonesia to buy more clothing to resell to customers and help pay school fees for her children.

She enjoys having this business because she does not have to sit at home all day and can be out meeting people and sharing stories with them.  Main challenges she faces with her business are when people cannot pay her and the increased competition.  If she ever has enough savings, she'd like to open her own store someday to sell the clothing and electronics from.

The other group members will use their loans to help their businesses which include selling cakes, selling ice, and selling cosmetics.

loans.use: to pay for clothing to resell to customers and pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana is 57 years old and lives in Catadman, Ozamiz City. She is married and has eight children. 

Juana has a rental-house business and she is a church caretaker who earns approximately PHP 5,000 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase materials for her boarding house repairs. 

Juana has been a member of PMPC for four years. In the future, Juana hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials for her boarding house repairs.

loans.name: Jeana

texts.en:
Jeana is 39 years old and lives in Bintangan, Larena, Siquijor.  She is married with three children.  Jeana has a backyard piggery to earn a living. She has been doing this for one year.  She has requested a loan of 7000 PHP to purchase feed and medicines for her piggery.

Jeana has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for one year.  Jeana hopes to become successful in her business and allow her children to finish studying.

loans.use: To purchase feed and medicines for her backyard piggery.

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is 30 years old, married, and has four children.  To earn a living, she does bicycle repairs and sells bicycle spare parts.  She has twelve years of experience in the business and has employed one person.  She also does farming for more income.

Damaris hopes to have a well-stocked spare parts shop in the future.  She has requested 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy bicycle spare parts.

loans.use: To buy bicycle spare parts.

loans.name: Precy

texts.en:
Precy has been engaged in her corn farm business for fifteen years and earns about P15,000 every harvest. She is also engaged in her sari-sari store (variety store) where she has been selling groceries, based in their home, for almost one year and earns P800 daily. She is willing to work hard every single day to lift her family out of poverty.
 
Precy is married to a farmer who helps her to manage their farm. According to her, through the income generated from her business she had been able to give daily allowances to her children who are currently in school.
 
At this time, she is requesting a loan of P 25,000 to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her corn production. She hopes that she can get the amount she requested to further develop her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her corn production.

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en:
Zipporah is 62 years old and a single mother of one child who is 32 years old.  To earn a living, she practices poultry farming.  She has been in the business for three years.  She is also employed elsewhere hence she has employed one person to run her business in her absence.

Zipporah hopes to expand her business in five years.  She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy chicks.

loans.use: To buy chicks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 57 years old and lives in Oroquieta City. She is married and has three children.
 
Evangeline has a dried fish business and earns approximately PHP 3,000 each month doing this work. She has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase more dried fish to sell.
 
Evangeline has been a member of PMPC for a year. In the future, Evangeline hopes to have a bigger dried fish business in order to meet their daily needs.

Evangeline is honest person, a hardworking mother and a loving wife. She takes good care of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a farmer in the Nkubu area of Central Kenya. She has been in farming for 20 years. Her farm currently produces milk, beans, tomatoes and bananas for the local market with the help of two farmhands.

She is married with five children: two adults and three minors who are still schooling.

Nancy has requested a loan of 70,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to enable her to purchase a water tank at 50,000 KES and irrigation pipes at 20,000 KES for better farming. She says installation of the irrigation system will improve her farming income and enable her to educate her children.

Nancy says they are challenged by the failure of rain and costly animal diseases. She is happy with Juhudi services, however, reiterating that the loans have changed the way farmers do their business.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank and irrigation pipes.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is married and has four children. She is 55 years old and lives in Mayor’s Village, Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.

Virginia has a general store to earn a living and has had this business for seven years. Each month, she earns PHP 15,000 doing this work. 

She has requested a loan for 14,900 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store.

Virginia has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, Virginia hopes to be more successful in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store.

location.town: Mayor Village Lapasan, Clarin Mis Occ

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Nestor has been managing his corn field for ten years. He is a responsible husband and father to his three children. His family is currently living within the village of Pinto Alfonso Lista, Ifugao. 

He is determined person since farming is the main source of their income. Nestor is aiming to improve their living status and educate all his three children. Through planting of additional crops, he hopes to increase his profit. 

Nestor doesn't have enough capital. That's the reason why he would like to borrow additional capital amounting to PHP 12,000, which will be used in buying farm supplies needed to improve his corn field. 

Nestor says that through this additional capital he can make his farming business more productive and give his family a better future.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies needed to improve his farming business.

loans.name: Francie

texts.en:
Francie is a married man with two school-age children. He is 40 years of age and lives in San Roque, Panaon Misamis Occidental. 

Francie sells fish to earn a living. His fish is in the motorcycle carrier box in the photo. He has been in this business for five years. He delivers fish on a door-to-door basis to his customer in different villages of Panaon, Misamis Occidental using his motorcycle. He has a net revenue of PHP 5,000 a month.

Francie joined GDMPC this year. He applied a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy supplementary fish to sell.

Francie, plans to sell more fish to improve his cash inflow to support the family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase supplementary fish to sell.

loans.name: Shameem's Group

texts.en:
Shameem is 41 years old and has four sons and two daughters. Her eldest son has a Punjabi food-selling business, which is called Samosay (made with potatoes and grum flour) while the other three are studying. Her two younger children are very young and they stay at home.

Shameem herself is a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighboring clients to financially support her family.

Shameem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her husband’s business. He makes hard paper boxes.
 
With the loan, he will purchase hard paper and gum in larger quantity for preparing boxes in larger number and increase his profits by selling them.

He is very experienced in his business and Shameem is confident that his business will be in a better position after the loan.

She is confident about the bright future of her family as a result of a loan investment
.
Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called the Asasah passbook) is Shameem.

loans.use: to buy gum and hard paper for making and selling paper boxes.

loans.name: Neuece

texts.en:
Neuece is a hardworking businesswoman, age 37. She is married and blessed with two children who are in school. 

For the last three years she has been selling clothes to support her family. She has employed two people to help her to manage the business. Neuece has been able to retain her business because of her good reputation with her customers. 

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to access loans to boost her business. She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to add to the stock of clothes for resale. 

In the next five years, she plans to establish a wholesale business.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes.

loans.name: Rael

texts.en:
Rael is a hardworking businesswoman and she is single. 

For the last year, she has been selling shoes and handbags to make a living. She also practices tea farming to supplement her income. She has employed two people to assist her to manage the business. 

Rael has been able to retain her business because of her good reputation with her customers. 

In the next five years, she wants to open another outlet of her business. She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy shoes and handbags for resale. 

Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has been able to adopt the culture of saving.

loans.use: To buy shoes and handbags.

loans.name: Hajran's Group

texts.en:
Hajran is 42 years old and illiterate, but she has the skills of sewing clothes. She uses her skills to earn profits for her family and pay for utilities. Hajran is also a very good housewife who performs her household duties very well along with her sewing works. 

Hajran is the mother of seven children. She couldn’t educate her children due to poor financial conditions, so all of them stay at home and don’t do anything.
 
Her husband is a building contractor. He builds buildings and houses on contract. He is a hard-working person who provides good quality services to his customers. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of both her husband's and her own businesses. Her husband will buy construction tools and she will buy a new sewing machine. The loan investment will help both Hajran and her husband improve their businesses and increase their income.
 
Both of them are hopeful that an investment will help them improve their business condition. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called the Asasah passbook) is Hajran.

loans.use: To buy construction tools and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Lilybeth

texts.en:
Lilybeth is divorced and has two children. She is thirty years old and lives in Molave, Zamboanga del Sur.

She requested a loan of 20,000 for her additional finances to go abroad.  

In the future, Lilybeth hopes that she can provide for the financial needs of her two children.

loans.use: finance for abroad

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David, 41, is a hardworking businessman. He is married and blessed with two children, both of whom attend school. 

He has been running a retail shop business to support his family. He also rents houses for more income. He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy rice and sugar for resale. 

In the next five years, David wants to expand his business. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access a loan to boost his business.

loans.use: to buy rice and sugar.

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Phorn, 35, is married and has one child. 

He started planting cassava ten years ago. To better support his family, he also buys soy beans and resells them to the market to generate additional income.
 
Phorn has been with VisionFund since 2009. He completely repaid his previous loans to VisionFund. Now he is applying for a third loan. He wants to buy soy beans to sell to the market and also plant cassava. 

With this loan, he hopes to increase his soy bean stock and his cassava crop. This will enable him to generate more income to feed his family and build some savings for the future.

loans.use: to plant cassava and buy soy beans for resale.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Lynette

texts.en:
Lynette is 40 years old and is married with four children. She lives in Pangi, Siquijor, Siquijor.  For the past seven years, she has run a business where she sells an assortment of food. Each month, she earns 5,000 PHP. Lynette has been a member of PMPC for one year.  

Lynette is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan to purchase ingredients for her food vending business. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is married and blessed with five children, all of whom attend school. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman. For the past year, Charles has been running an Internet cafe to support his family. He has employed two people to assist him with his business. 

Charles is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy a printer. Within the next five years, he plans to open a computer college.

loans.use: to buy a printer

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza is 38 years old and is married with three children. She lives in Sebasi, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. For the past 10 years, she has been a farmer who produces corn to earn a living. Liza has been a member of PMPC for one year.

Liza is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to purchase fertilizer to maintain her corn production. In the future, she hopes to be successful in her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer to maintain her crop

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is 36 years old and is married with a four year old child. For the past four years, he has been farming in his home area of Nkubu, Central Kenya. Nicholas grows maize, beans, and bananas on his farm along with milk that he sells to the local market. He also operates as a chemist in the local market and his major business challenge is the high rate of animal disease.

Nicholas is requesting a 60,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to help him venture into pig farming business by buying pigs and feed. This is his second loan request with Juhudi after promptly repaying his first 30,000 KES loan. Nicholas says that his new venture will strengthen his farming business and generate more income due to the high rate at which pigs reproduce. He will use his income to pay for his child’s education and he plans to buy more land to cultivate.

loans.use: to purchase pigs and pig feed

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 33 years old, married, and blessed with three children, all of whom attend school. He is a hardworking businessman who has been engaged in the business of repairing phones and selling phone accessories for the last two years. Vincent has been able to support his family and retain his business because of good reputation with his customers. 

Vincent is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy phone accessories for resale.  He hopes to expand his business in the next five years.

loans.use: to buy phone accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add to her stock of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Theodora

texts.en:
Theodora is a 36-year-old lady, married to Alfret, 42 years old. They have three children. Two of her children are under 11 years old and attending school while the youngest child is not at school yet.

Theodora runs a food stall business which sells fried rice, yellow rice (made with coconut milk and turmeric) with side dishes, snacks and cold beverages. The business is located at an elementary school near her residence. 

Prior to running a food stall business Theodora used to sell clothing, shoes and bags from one house to another. She ran the business for three years and stopped the business once she had her youngest child. Theodara enjoys her current business as it is only operated for seven hours a day. 
 
Now Theodora is seeking a loan amounting to IDR 3,000,000 from TLM to purchase more snacks, instant beverages as demanded by the customer (particularly the children at school) and a refrigerator. She hopes that TLM will help her by providing the loan to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase more snacks, instant beverages and a refrigerator.

loans.name: Janna's Group

texts.en:
Janna is the leader of this group. She is 43 and married to a builder. Together with her husband, she has raised three sons. Two older sons live independently from their parents and the youngest son studies at school. 

A year ago Janna saved some money to rent a store. She started to sell different products such as beverages, chewing gum, and chocolate. She invests the profits gained from the trade back in her business, purchasing goods to increase the commodity turnover in her store. With money received from the loan she will mostly purchase beverages. In the future, Janna wishes to have her own store.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase beverages.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie, age 53 and widowed, sells ready-to-wear clothing products to earn a living. She has operated this business for 10 years and earns PHP 3,000. She lives in Bagacay, Larena, Siquijor. She has four children.
 
Elvie has been a member of the Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for five months. She has requested a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 in order to purchase ready-to-wear clothes to offer for sale.

In the future, Elvie aspires to better meet client demand and expectation and to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase ready-to-wear clothes to offer for sale

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is 50 years of age. She is very active and sews clothes to support her family financially. She works for clients in her community and earns good profits every month due to the quality of her work.

Her husband operates a barber shop in the market. He is an expert in cutting hair. He also offers beauty treatments to his customers from his barber shop.

Nasreen has given birth to 3 sons and a daughter. Her eldest son also operates a barber shop while her daughter stays at home and helps Nasreen with her household tasks.

Nasreen has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her husband's business. He wants to buy scissors, shaving gel and beauty products to improve his services. Nasreen’s husband is experienced in his business and Nasreen is confident that this loan will be beneficial for him.

loans.use: to buy scissors, shaving gel and beauty products for her husband's barber shop

loans.name: Cornelis

texts.en:
Cornelis, 32 years old, is married. He has two children: Veby, 8 and Yacob, 7, and both are attending elementary school. As the breadwinner Cornelis works hard to meet his family's daily needs and pay the education fees of his children.

Cornelis runs a home business producing “tempeh” (fermented soybean cake). He used to work in a tempeh factory for two years. Equipped with skills learnt from his previous job, Cornelis initiated his own business.
 
In running the business, Cornelis is assisted by his wife. In a day he is able to ferment up to 100 kg of soybean. The fermentation would take about two days before the tempeh can be sold. 
	
Cornelis is requesting a loan from TLM amounting to IDR 10,000,000 to purchase sacks of soybean and firewood to produce more tempeh. He is sure that the loan will support him in improving the business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of soybeans and firewood.

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.en:
Eugenio, age 40, owns and operates a motorcycle transport known as a "habal-habal" business in order to earn a living. Eugenio has been engaged in this business for about five years. This is the principal source of income for Eugenio. He earns about PhP 5,000 a month.

Eugenio lives in Mitugas, Tudela Misamis Occidental, with his wife and two school-aged children. His wife works as a fish vendor.

Earlier this year, Eugenio joined GDMPC. He has requested a loan of PhP 5,000 to purchase spare parts in order to make necessary repairs to his motorcycle. In the future, Eugenio plans to purchase another motorcycle for transport so as to improve his overall cash return.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts in order to make necessary repairs to his motorcycle

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo, age 53, is a responsible and diligent father who strives to ensure good crop production on his one-hectare plot of land, where he plants and harvest rice to sell. He has been cultivating it for over 20 years and earns about P30,000 each harvest season, which falls during the months of April and November. He also raises hogs for an additional income.

Eduardo and his wife have five children. Four have settled into marriage and one is pursuing a college education. 

Eduardo needs to improve his crop production to save enough money for the family's daily needs and for the sustenance of his hogs. Because he has insufficient funds, he is asking for a loan of PhP 30,000 to pay for land cultivation and to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides for his farm.

In the future, Eduardo would like to improve his farming practices so that his farm can continuously yield good crops.

loans.use: to pay for land cultivation and to buy seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides for his farm

loans.name: Dolgormaa

texts.en: Dolgormaa is 41 years old and lives with her husband and a son in the city of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband works in the countryside and her son studies at a local elementary school. She started her grocery retail business in 2003 and, as a result, her shop is very well known around the neighborhood. Her daily income is 500,000-600,000 MNT and she bought an apartment with the profit. Now that many new buildings have been built in the neighborhood, she needs to broaden her product range in order to keep up with the new demand. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who said, "There are many new buildings around here and it is my chance to expand my business." She is requesting 3,000,000 MNT to buy more products.

loans.use: to buy more products.

loans.name: Damiana

texts.en:
Damiana, age 59, has a welding shop business and earns approximately PHP 5,000 each month. She lives in Tawi-tawi, Aloran, Misamis Occidental, with her family. She and her husband have had raised nine children. 

She has requested a loan of in the amount of 14,900 to purchase essential equipment for her welding shop.

Damiana has been a member of PMPC for three years.

loans.use: to purchase essential equipment for her welding shop

loans.name: Paula

texts.en:
Paula, 30 years old, is married to Maksi who is a taxi driver. They are blessed with two children namely: Yohanis, 4 years old and Vanessa, 6 months old. 

In order to support her husband in covering their daily needs, Paula sells kerosene. She has been engaged in the business since 2008. In addition to selling kerosene Paula also sells cakes and pudding based on customers' orders. 

Paula dreams of enlarging her cake business; she hopes that she can buy a freezer, stove and an oven to support her business. She is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000. She hopes that TLM can assist her to get the loan soon.

loans.use: to purchase a freezer, stove and an oven.

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene is 37 years old and lives in Caipilan, Siquijor, Siquijor.  He is separated from his wife. He has two children.

Eugene is engaged in growing pigs to earn a living.  He earns PHP 7,000 each  month doing this type of work. He has requested a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to purchase feed and medicines for his piggery.

He has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for one month. Eugene would like to see his children finish their studies.

loans.use: To purchase feed and medicines for his piggery.

loans.name: Magogoni Group

texts.en:
Malaki, who is in his mid 30s, is married with two children who go to school.  He has had a motorcycle business for one year now.  He works from 6 am to 8 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be his second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to start building his house and has paid back his loan successfully.  He wants a loan to finish building his house.  His dream is to one day be able to buy another motorcycle and "bajaji" (automated rickshaw),  

He will share this loan with his loan group "Magogoni" which has a total of 16 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to finish building his house.

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en:
Franklin, a 51-year-old married father of four children, has worked as a farmer for 20 years, growing corn to generate an income to feed his family, earning P17,000 per cropping season. Despite hardships suffered in his field, Franklin devotes his time to planting and plowing the farmland to make it as productive as possible.

High interest rates on farm supplies are a major business expense, one that could be significantly reduced were he to purchase his supplies from other sellers offering low interest rates, but his funds are not sufficient to take advantage of the situation. Franklin is therefore requesting a loan of P27,000 to purchase farm supplies such as herbicides, insecticides, fertilizer and certified seed. He aspires to be a very a successful farmer in the future.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies such as herbicides, insecticides, fertilizers and certified seed for his corn field.

loans.name: Olympio

texts.en: Olympio is 45 years old and lives in Baybay Triunfo, Ozamiz City. He is separated and has one child. Olympio owns and operates a business providing transport to local community members for a living. He has been doing this for five years. He has requested a loan of PHP 30,000 to purchase a slightly used motorcycle. Olympio is a new member of PMPC. In the future, Olympio hopes to save money for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase a slightly used motorcycle

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en: Myagmarsuren is 32 years old and lives with his wife and three kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife babysits her newborn baby and two of the kids are school students. He started his wooden craft business in 2005 by making his products at home. Now that his products are well known, product demand is increasing and he needs to buy new equipment to speed up the process. He is requesting 1,500,000 MNT to buy new equipment and wood materials.

loans.use: To buy new equipment and wood materials.

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en:
Hoeurn is 38 years old and married. She has 4 children. For the last 15 years, she has been farming to support her living. To better feed her family, she also does a plantation on the site and works for others to generate additional income.

This is her second loan with VisionFund. She completely repaid her first loan and now she is requesting a loan to rent a plot to plant cassava. This loan will enable her to generate more income from planting to better feed her family and build some savings for the future.

loans.use: to rent a plot to plant cassava

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence, 27, is single. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are clothing, food and electricity bills.

Florence has operated a taxi business for the past five years; her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other taxi operators in the area. She dreams of purchasing another car for her taxi business in the future.

With the 60,000 KES she wants to purchase bales of clothes to start a clothes-selling business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for clothes-selling business.

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en: Erdenetsetseg is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar City, Mongolia. Her husband runs a woolen clothes manufacturing business, her elder daughter is studying in Malaysia, and the younger one is studying in China. She used to work with her husband at his manufacturing business, but in 2010, she started her own garment retailing business by renting two counters in the biggest market in Mongolia. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says, "Now that my kids are studying abroad, I need to expand my business in order to support them." She is requesting MNT 1,500,000 to buy more garments.

loans.use: to buy more garments.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is married with five school-age children. Jocelyn is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Jocelyn is a farmer and grows pigs for sale to earn a living. She has been doing this for two years. She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Jocelyn has been a member of PMPC for 3 years. In the future, Jocelyn hopes to have enough savings for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and vitamins for pigs

loans.name: Estela

texts.en:
Estela is a 46-year-old widow with two school-age children. Estela lives in Taraka, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental.

Estela owns and operates a "habal-habal" motorcycle transport service business to earn a living. Estela has been engaged in this business for about two years. This is the principal source of income for Ms. Estela and she earns about PHP 5,000 a month.

Early this year Estela joined GDMPC. Estela requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to repair a motorcycle transport vehicle. In the future, Estela plans to purchase another motorcycle for transport to gain supplementary income.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle

loans.name: Maryam's Group

texts.en:
Maryam is a 43-year-old widow. Her husband died a few years ago leaving her alone with 2 children. Maryam never lost hope and worked very hard to raise her children. Due to poor financial conditions, she couldn’t educate her youngest son. Only her eldest son is able to continue his studies and studying in 12th standard. Her nephew also lives with her and operates a Punjabi food restaurant through which he sells a variety of food to his customers. 

Maryam is a seamstress, sewing clothes for her neighboring clients. She is very skillful and receives a good number of orders every month. 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine that will allow her to complete orders on time and earn more profit.  

She is confident that after the loan investment, she will be able to increase her income and provide better living facilities to her family.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for expansion of her sewing business.

loans.name: Warren

texts.en:
Warren is proud that he is a farmer. He has managed his cornfield for over 15 years and he earns about PHP 20,000 per cropping season. Though he experiences hardships in running his farming business, he still endures everything to feed his family and educate his only child. Warren would now like to increase his profit because his income last crop season was used in paying all his obligations to traders who offered high interest rates. According to him, he will not get tired of farming in the field since his main goal is to uplift their living conditions. 

Warren would like to request a loan amounting to PHP 27,000, which would allow him to buy farm inputs for his farming business. He hopes that this loan amount will help him to increase his yield.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs for his farming business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 32 years old, married and has two children.  To earn a living, she runs a retail shop.  She has been in the business for five years.  She also does dairy farming to supplement her income.  Mary works hard in her business so as to provide for her family.

In the next five years, she hopes to expand her retail shop into a wholesale business.  She needs a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sugar, rice, wheat flour and soap.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, wheat flour and soap

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en: Winnie is a hardworking businesswoman aged 53. She is single and blessed with two children. She has been running a cafeteria business to support her family. She has employed three people to help her to manage the business. Her potential customers are passersby and the local residents. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy more chairs and sodas for her business. In the next 5 years, she wants to open a restaurant.

loans.use: To buy chairs and sodas.

loans.name: Barkah Mandiri Group

texts.en:
Dewi has been selling juice from a stand in front of her house since 2009.  She is pictured in the photo above wearing the green shirt with the white collar, standing with her group in front of her juice stand.  She is 27 years old and married with one child. Her child is four and a half years old and is not old enough for school yet.  Her husband works as an employee at a cafe.  She hopes that with both of their incomes, they will have enough money to send their child to school when it is old enough.

Her business has been going well because she has many customers.  She is taking her first loan with VisionFund Indonesia to purchase more fruit, straws, cups and a blender.  The blender will enable her to start selling iced drinks to keep up with her competitors.  Eventually she would like to expand her stand to start selling cooked noodles as well.  A few challenges she faces are  that there are competitors in her neighborhood and also sometimes customers owe her money.  Her favorite part of the business is that it allows her to take care of her child while she is selling juice.  She also likes meeting new people through her juice stand.   

The other group members will use their loans to improve their businesses which include, catering, selling pastries, selling "kerupuk" (Indonesian crackers), and sewing.

loans.use: to pay for fruit, straws, cups, and a blender.

loans.name: Essowédewou

texts.fr:
Essowédewou est une femme âgée de 39 ans. Elle est mariée à un chauffeur et est mère de 3 enfants tous scolarisés. L’ainé de la famille a 25 ans et le benjamin 17 ans.  
Essowédewou travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2001. Elle achète et revend du charbon de bois et du maïs à toutes personnes à son domicile. Elle s’approvisionne régulièrement dans les villages de l’intérieur du pays, et travaille seule. 
Essowédewou a requis son troisième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des sacs de charbon et de maïs destinés à la vente. Elle prévoit réinvestir les profits supplémentaires de son activité dans la diversification des marchandises. 
Dans les prochaines années, Essowédewou voudrait aussi du haricot et des ignames. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit acheter une moto pour les déplacements de ces enfants.
texts.en:
Essowédewou, age 39, is married to a driver and the mother of three school-attending children. The eldest is 25 years old, and the youngest is 17.

Essowédewou has been a reseller since 2001. She buys charcoal and corn, and resells them to a diverse clientele at her home.

She gets her supplies on a regular basis from villages in the interior of the country, and works on her own.

She's seeking her third loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, in order to buy sacks of charcoal and corn to resell. 

She intends to reinvest the additional profits in her business, in order to diversify her products.

In the forthcoming years, Essowédewou would like to offer beans and yams as well. 

She says that she will use her profits to buy a motorcycle to transport her children.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal and corn to resell

loans.name: Changara Kumbukumbu Group

texts.en:
Receive greetings from Changara Kumbukumbu Group in Western Kenya! Tom is the facilitator of the group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Tom takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Tom had a good maize yield harvesting 6 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Tom was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Tom and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Tom will educate his children and ensure food security for his family.

In 2012, the members of Changara Kumbukumbu group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Tom is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac is married and blessed with one child who is in school. For the last ten years, he has been selling clothes to support his family. His potential customers are his local residents. Isaac has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenya shillings to add stock of clothes for resale. In the next 5 years, he wants to own a boutique. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been able to adopt the culture of saving.

loans.use: To add stock of clothing.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha is a single woman, aged 43. She is blessed with one child, who is in school. For the last four years, she has been running a printing business to make a living. She is also employed elsewhere. Martha has employed one person to assist in her business. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy stationery. In the next five years, she wants to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy stationery.

loans.name: Msamaria Mwema Group

texts.en:
Bramwel is the facilitator of the Msamaria Mwema group. He and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Bramwel takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to grow enough to feed his family and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Bramwel had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on 1 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Bramwel was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Bramwel and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Bramwel will educate his children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Msamaria Mwema group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Bramwel is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Luvsandavaa

texts.en:
Luvsandavaa is 59 years old and lives with his wife in a 'ger' (Mongolian yurt) in Tuv province, Mongolia. His wife helps with his business and his kids are all independent. He started his billiard and table tennis service business in 2003. Now that his billiard and table tennis equipment and workspace are old, nobody wants to play there. Therefore he needs to replace the tables and fix up the environment. 

Luvsandavaa is a sharp and hardworking man who says, "Now that my kids are independent, it is time to expand my business." He is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to buy billiard and table tennis equipment.

loans.use: To buy billiard and table tennis equipment.

loans.name: Sairagul's Group

texts.en:
Sairagul is the leader of this group. She is 43 and married. Her spouse works in construction. Five years ago with an initial investment of 20,000 soms she purchased cattle, and since that time she has engaged in cattle breeding. By selling dairy products, Sairagul earns about 2000 soms to meet family needs. In case they need money to cover daily expenses she can sell some cattle. With money received from the loan Sairagul plans to purchase hay for feeding cattle during the winter season. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase hay

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: in her farming business and will allow her to buy some small fish to raise.

loans.name: Bidii Women Group

texts.en:
Rhidah is the facilitator of the Bidii Women's Group. Rhidah and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rhidah takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Rhidah had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Rhidah was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rhidah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Rhidah will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Bidii Women's group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Rhidah is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two kids in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her husband is a driver, her elder son is a clerk and the younger one is a school student. She started her garment retailing business in 2008 by renting a counter in a local market. She was a sewer in a local cashmere factory and so she has a very good eye for fashion. 

Now that winter is approaching, she needs more warmer clothes to sell. She is a bright and hardworking woman who is requesting 1,000,000 MNT to buy more clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en:
Augustine is a resident and a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya where he has been producing  and selling maize for the local market. He is married with eight children,  five of whom are still schooling. He is works as an electrician for additional income.

Augustine has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a motorcycle for  a venture into the transport business. He says there is a current boom in the business and it will help him in improving his family's living standards. He says the transport business will supplement his farming income.


He says  the unreliability of the rains  and the high costs of farm inputs are the major challenges in farming .

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Banzragch

texts.en:
Banzragch is a loving father of four who is disabled. His wife is a janitor. His eldest daughter works in city, his middle two are college students, and his youngest child is unemployed. Banzragch started his carpentry business in 1985 at home. He makes gers (Mongolian yurts), wooden walls, and Mongolian traditional furniture. Now that winter is approaching, he needs to update his equipment due to high business demand. 

Banzragch is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to buy timber and other materials. He is a strong and hardworking man who says, “I have four wonderful children. I will do everything I can in order to get them educated.”

loans.use: to buy timber and other materials

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a mother of five children between the ages of four and 12. She lives with her family in their home in Kitale. For the last six years, she has been a farmer and she produces milk and maize for the local market. Catherine laments the high costs of farm inputs and animal disease management. 

Catherine is requesting a 60,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a motorcycle to venture into the transport business. Catherine plans to begin this business because she sees potential for growth. She also hopes to improve her farming business.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen is requesting another Kiva loan of 10,000 KES to start up a new business distributing water. She also sells paraffin and operates a beauty salon to provide an income. Hellen will use her loan to purchase water pipes which will improve her living standard. Hellen dreams of expanding her beauty salon business.

loans.use: to purchase water pipes

loans.name: Jitegemee Shg Group

texts.en:
Receive greetings from Jitegemee SHG Group in Western Kenya! Ezekiel is the facilitator of the Jitegemee SHG group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Ezekiel is a father of three children. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to feed his family and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds for quality harvest. In the recent 2011 season, Ezekiel had a very good maize yield harvesting 11 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Ezekiel was only able to harvest three bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ezekiel and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Ezekiel will save for future use and invest in livestock

He is pictured in the photograph with his group members. On the far left is their Field Officer.

In 2012, the members of Jitegemee SHG group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 22 years old and single. For the past two years, he has run a retail shop to earn a living. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to improve his business because has received business management training. 

James is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy cooking fat, sugar, salt, and wheat flour. In the future, he hopes to expand his business into wholesale

loans.use: to buy cooking fat, sugar, salt, and wheat flour

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en:
Ganbaatar is 53 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Since 1974, Ganbaatar has been working as a welder and he opened his own home welding business in 2005. His wife and daughter help with his business and his son works in city. Ganbaatar is well known for his excellent work and his equipment is portable equipment which gives him an advantage over his competitors. 

Ganbaatar recently received a mass order from a company and he is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to buy thin and thick iron.

loans.use: to buy iron

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra is 42, married and her husband has a business of making and selling shoes. He makes a variety of shoes and is very good with his customers in his dealings and makes good sales every month.
 
Azra is a seamstress who sews clothes for her neighboring clients and is very skillful in her work.
 
She is the mother of two sons and three daughters. Three of them are studying while her eldest son left his education after fifth standard and started a furniture polishing business.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s shoemaking business. With the loan, he will buy shoemaking material like leather, nails and shoe polisher in bulk that will allow him to make more shoes and sell them for a higher price.
 
Azra is very confident that her husband’s business will be improved further after the loan investment.
 
Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called the Asasah passbook) is Azra.

loans.use: To buy shoe-making materials for shoe-making business.

loans.name: Ngano Na Ngano Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Ngano na Ngano Group in Western Kenya! David heads the group as its facilitator. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

David takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, David had a very good maize yield harvesting 15 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, David was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to David and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, David will ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Ngano na Ngano group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

He is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Byambasuren is 20, single and lives with his parents and sister in Ulaanbaatar city in Mongolia. 

His father drives a truck, his mother is unemployed and his sister is a pharmacist. 

He started his taxi service business in 2009 with his own car. He loves his business. Now that winter is approaching, he needs to maintain his car for the harsh winter. He is a sharp and hardworking man who said, "I do everything to expand my business. I even have regular customers who just call me when they need a taxi."

He is requesting 1,000,000 MNT to buy a wheel rim.

loans.use: To buy a wheel rim.

loans.name: Dédé

texts.fr:
Dédé est une femme  âgé(e) de 25 ans. Elle est célibataire. 
Dédé est revendeuse de boisson VODKA depuis 2010. Elle vend à ses clients de façon ambulante après achat ACCRA.
Dédé a requis son premier  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter de la boisson VODKA pour  revendre.
texts.en: Dédé is a 25-year old single woman. She has been selling vodka since 2010 and does so on a door-to-door basis once she has bought it in Accra. She has requested her first loan from WAGES in order to buy vodka for resale.

loans.use: to buy vodka

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 25 and married with three children between 9 and 2. 

She has been practicing farming in Kitale in Western Kenya for the last two years, producing and selling milk and maize for the local market, and she employs one farmhand. She also runs a grocery business within the local market.

Christine has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a motorcycle for a transport business. She says she wants to use the income from the transport business to expand her farm acreage by buying more land. She adds the new businesses will also improve the living standards of her family.

Christine laments of animal diseases and unreliable rainfall as the major challenges in farming.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.en:
Cholpon is the leader of this group. She is 35 and together with her husband, she is bringing up three children. 

In order to earn money to live, Cholpon takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national caps and hats. With the profits gained from this activity, Cholpon buys livestock for breeding. Her husband has been engaged in livestock breeding for about ten years. 

With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of caps and hats to increase the assortment of goods that she sells. In the future Cholpon wants to open her own sewing workshop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase caps and hats.

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida is married and is 49 years of age. She is a housewife and performs her household duties by staying at home. Zubaida is the mother of an 18-year-old son who does a job.

Her husband has been involved in a Punjabi food restaurant for the past eight years through which he sells traditional local food (daal chawal and roti, made with lentils and served with rice and bread) at reasonable rates. The quality of food he offers is very good and he earns a good income from his business. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband's restaurant business. With the loan, he will buy required ingredients like lentils, rice, spices, cooking oil and flour for making food in larger quantity to provide better quality food to his clients.
 
Zubaida is very hopeful that this will be a productive investment for her husband and it will increase his profits. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. Previously, she has established a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy required ingredients for the restaurant business.

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en: Matilda is a married woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. For the past four years, Matilda has operated a business selling Khangas (clothing). She sells door to door, to her neighbours, and passersby. Her major business challenge is seasonality. Matilda dreams of expanding her business in the future. With a loan of Kshs 20,000 she would like to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Davaasuren

texts.en: Davaasuren's husband earns a living by driving a taxi, but recently his vehicle was damaged and he is no longer able to use it to generate an income. She is applying for this loan to cover the cost of renovating her husband's taxi so that he can go back to work.

loans.use: to repair and renovate a taxi.

loans.name: Shinebayar

texts.en:
Mrs. Shinebayar is a 26-year-old, and is host of a Vietnam auto-repair service. She lives with her daughter in a rental apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. When she was a student, she was introduced to, and became friends with, some Vietnam guys.  She started her business with the friends initially. Now there are 3 employees working in her auto-repair service. 

She has a plan to  increase the number of employees in order to expand the business scope.  She will hire 2 employees from Vietnam.  She needs money for expenses related to visa payments, travel to Mongolia, and their salaries.  The loan she is taking will be dedicated to hiring new employees from abroad for her auto-repair service.

loans.use: To hire new employees from abroad for her auto-repair service.

loans.name: Mawar Grace Group

texts.en:
Lasmiatun is 48 years old and married with three children. Two of her children are still going to school. Her first daughter, Yustin, has already finished high school.  She wants to go to University but they don't have enough money so she has found a job. Lasmiatun's business is making and selling gado-gado (Indonesian dish). She has been doing this since 2007. She works with her husband. This is her second loan with VisionFund Indonesia. She wants to use this loan to pay for more vegetables to make gado-gado and pay for school fees for her other two children. Now she has three competitors around her neighborhood so she needs more money to buy ingredients to expand her business. She hopes she can also find a more strategic place to do this business.

Some of the other group members will use their loans to improve their businesses, which include selling fruit, selling Indonesian dishes, and teaching aerobics.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to make gado-gado (Indonesian dish) and pay for school fees for children

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en:
Farida is the leader of this group. She is 28 and married to a tax inspector. Together with her husband she brings up a two year-old son. Farida works as a bookkeeper in a bank. A few years ago, the couple decided to save money from their salary and invest the savings in livestock breeding. In their opinion it is an effective way of investing money. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase livestock for breeding, fattening and further reselling. In the future Farida wishes to save money to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past nine years, she has operated a nursery school for young children from the neighboring community. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her school to incorporate upper classes in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase cement and timber to expand her classrooms. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cement and timber to expand her classrooms.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy ladies' handbags, clothes, and ladies' and men's footwear

loans.name: Set

texts.en: Mrs. Set is 60 years old and a mother of three children. She is a local farmer, working alongside her husband from Prey Chor district, Kompong Cham. She has been engaged in the farming business for years. She has learned how to do it well from her parents and it is her only income. She usually earns approximately of $2.00 per day through farming. As shown in the picture, she’s standing in front of her house with her daughter. This house was built a long time ago. Currently, it’s partially broken and requires repairs immediately. Therefore, she’s seeking some funds from HKL and Kiva to fix some parts of her house. With rest of these funds, she wants to build a room made of brick under her wooden house. She is grateful to all the kind funders and she says that she won’t make a late payment of her loan.

loans.use: to fix some parts of her house and build a room made of brick under her wooden house.

loans.name: Twigishanye Ii Group

texts.fr:
Claire est une commerçante âgée de 29ans qui habite la localité de Rutonde de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle fait le commerce des habits usagers (friperie) depuis 9 ans. Elle avait un restaurant avant de changer pour cette actuelle activité. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Elle est mariée a Salvator et ont ensemble 2 enfants dont 1étudie. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 300,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de beaucoup plus d’habits usagers (friperie) à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses économies. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« TWIGISHANYE II»
texts.en:
Claire is a 29-year-old storekeeper who lives in Rutonde, in the province of Gitega in the center of the country. She has been in the business of selling secondhand clothing for 9 years. She used to have a restaurant before starting this business. She completed 6 years of schooling. She is married to Salvator and they have two children together, with one in school. 
The Kiva loan of 300,000 francs will help her to increase her capital to purchase a large quantity of secondhand clothing in order to resell them at a high return and to increase her savings.

She is a member of the community group "TWIGISHANYE II."

loans.use: to increase her capital to purchase a large quantity of secondhand clothing in order to resell them at a high return and to increase her savings.

loans.name: Enkhzaya

texts.en: Mrs. Enkhzaya, 24, is a waitress in a French restaurant in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She lives with her husband and her son in an apartment in the boundary district of Ulaanbaatar. Since her family moved into that apartment, they have not made any adjustments or renovations. It has become very old and uncomfortable to live there. Therefore Enkhzaya is taking a loan to purchase some building materials to renovate her apartment.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for renovation

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana is 29 years old. She has studied up to primary school and supports her husband financially by sewing clothes for her neighboring clients. Her husband sells wheat, cotton, rice, and other agricultural products. He is illiterate, but he has good business management skills and is running his business very well. Rehana is the mother of six children. None of them is getting an education due to the poor financial situation of Rehana and her husband. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her business sewing clothes. With the loan investment she will buy a new sewing machine because her current machine has grown old and needs to be replaced. By purchasing a new sewing machine she will be able to complete the orders on time and will also be able to run her business better. She has been operating her business for the past many years and is very confident about the success of her business after the loan investment. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Pascalia

texts.en:
Pascalia is a married woman with two children who attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent, and electricity.

For the past five years, she has operated a beauty salon and cosmetic business. Her potential customers are neighbours and passers-by. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.  

With the 40,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase cosmetics to improve her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Munguntuya

texts.en:
Munguntuya is 24 years old and has one child.  Since 2008 she has been working as a photographer and runs a taxi business in the evening. 

Munguntuya uses a Japanese camera, which was damaged a month ago and cannot be fixed. She is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy a new camera for her job.

loans.use: to purchase a new camera.

loans.name: Twigishanye I Group

texts.fr:
Fides est une commerçante âgée de 40ans qui habite à la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle fait le commerce d’articles divers de boutique (farine de manioc et de mais, huile pour la cuisson, haricot, sel, riz, bonbons, souliers, dentifrices…) depuis 5 ans. Elle était tailleur avant de commencer cette activité. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont 4étudient. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 300,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités d’articles de boutique (farine de manioc et de mais, huile pour la cuisson, haricot, sel, riz, bonbons, souliers, dentifrices…) à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses économies. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« TWIGISHANYE I»
texts.en:
Fides is a 40-year-old merchant who lives in the province of Gitega in the center of the country. For five years she has been selling various articles (cassava flour and maize, cooking oil, beans, salt, rice, candy, shoes, toothpaste...). 

Before starting this activity she was a seamstress. She attended school up to sixth grade. She is married and the mother of five children, four of them are in school. 

 The Kiva loan of 300,000 Burundian francs allows her to increase her capital to buy items in large quantities for her shop (cassava flour and maize, cooking oil, beans, salt, rice, candy, shoes, toothpaste...). She can resell them in order to realize large profits and increase her savings.

She is a member of the community group "TWIGISHANYE I"

loans.use: to increase her capital to buy items in large quantities for her shop (cassava flour and maize, cooking oil, beans, salt, rice, candy, shoes, toothpaste...) and resell them in order to realize large profits.

loans.name: Banguka I Group

texts.fr:
Rose est une commerçante âgée de 62ans qui habite la localité de Kwibuka de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle vend des articles divers dans sa boutique (haricot, riz, huile de palme, savon, pétrole, biscuits,…) depuis 30 ans, un métier qu’elle commence alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Elle est mariée a David et ont ensemble 10 enfants dont 4 déjà maries et tous les autres étudient même a l’Université. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 250,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité d’articles divers pour sa boutique(  haricot, riz, huile de palme, savon, pétrole, biscuits,…) à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses économies. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire «GARUKIRABAKENYEZI»
texts.en:
Rose is a 62 year old merchant who lives in the town of Kwibuka of the province of Gitega in the centre of the country. For 30 years, she  has been selling various items in her shop (beans, rice, palm oil, soap, gasoline, biscuits, ...). She started this job when she was a farmer. She did not attend school. She is married to David and together they have 10 children, four of them are already married and all the others are in school even studying at the University.

Kiva’s loan of 250,000 Burundian francs allows her to increase her capital to purchase large quantities of various items for her store (beans, rice, palm oil, soap, gasoline, biscuits, ...). She resells them in order to make large profits and increase her savings.

She is a member of the community group "Garukirabakenyezi”.

loans.use: to increase her capital to buy a large quantity of various items for her shop (beans, rice, palm oil, gasoline, biscuits ...) and resell them to make large profits and increase her savings.

loans.name: Karlygash's Group

texts.en:
Karlygash leads this three-person loan group. She is 21, married to a taxi driver and has two children, a daughter and a son, neither of whom is yet old enough to attend school. She cares for her children at home during the day but also works on the side as a livestock breeder. She started this business five years ago with an investment of 5,000 soms, and is applying for this loan to buy more animals for her herd. In the future, she plans to buy furniture to improve her family's living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy more livestock

loans.name: Garukirabakenyezi Group

texts.fr:
Rose est une commerçante âgée de 62ans qui habite la localité de Kwibuka de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle vend des articles divers dans sa boutique (haricot, riz, huile de palme, savon, pétrole, biscuits,…) depuis 30 ans, un métier qu’elle commence alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Elle est mariée a David et ont ensemble 10 enfants dont 4 déjà maries et tous les autres étudient même a l’Université. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 250,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité d’articles divers pour sa boutique(  haricot, riz, huile de palme, savon, pétrole, biscuits,…) à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses économies. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« GARUKIRABAKENYEZI»
texts.en: Rose is a 62-year old vendor living in the village of Kwibuka in the Province of Gitega in the center of the country. She has been selling miscellaneous items (beans, rice palm oil, soap, fuel, cookies etc) for 30 years, a business she launched back when she was also doing farm work. She did not go to school. She is married to a man by the name of David. They have 10 children together, four of whom are already married and all others study, [some] even at the university level. A Kiva loan of 250,000 Burundian francs will allow her to increase her work capital in order to buy a large stock of various goods (beans, rice palm oil, soap, fuel, cookies etc) to resell in her store and thus increase her revenue and grow her savings.   She is a member of the Garukirabakenyezi Community group.

loans.use: increase her work capital in order to buy a large stock of various goods  (beans, rice palm oil, soap, fuel, cookies etc)

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en: Sajida stayed in school as far as the fifth grade, but had to leave at that point to go to work because her family was so poor. She is now married and has six children. Her husband earns a living by providing transportation services on a rickshaw. Her oldest son works in a factory and two of her children are still in school. She is applying for this loan from Kiva partner Asasah to repair her husband's rickshaw so that he can provide improved transportation services. He has been in this line of work for 10 years and is very experienced. Sajida is confident that this loan will allow him to increase his profits.

loans.use: to repair a rickshaw.

loans.name: Ariuntuya

texts.en: Mrs. Ariuntuya runs a grocery store and wants to support and join to her friend's carpenter business. Her friend Nyamsuren works as a carpenter and has been doing his business for 3 years. Every fall, Nyamsuren preserve his business working material-wood from the suppliers. Because during winter time his carpentry raw material-wood becomes very rare and expensive in the market.
